[7] Differences in symptoms and lung function could not be explained by age, smoking status or employment at another flavouring plant. [1] Conclusions Symptoms and lung function findings were consistent with undiagnosed or subclinical obliterative bronchiolitis and associated with workplace exposures. [2] Further efforts to lower exposures to flavouring chemicals, including diacetyl substitutes, are warranted. [1] Efforts to address adverse respiratory effects of flavouring manufacture that focus solely on diacetyl exposure reduction are unlikely to be successful. [2] Until the safety of other flavouring chemicals is established, exposure reduction (such as through enhanced ventilation and use of respiratory protection) and medical surveillance are prudent. [1] Occupational exposure to the butter flavouring chemical diacetyl has been associated with obliterative bronchiolitis (also known as bronchiolitis obliterans) in the microwave popcorn, diacetyl manufacture and coffee processing industries.

llm_generation.summary: In this context, Butane-2,3-dione, also known as diacetyl, is identified as a specific flavoring chemical associated with adverse respiratory effects, particularly obliterative bronchiolitis, in occupational settings. The discussion emphasizes the need for exposure reduction to flavoring chemicals, indicating that Butane-2,3-dione is a representative example of the broader category of chemicals that pose health risks in the workplace. However, the relationship is primarily focused on the specific health implications of Butane-2,3-dione rather than a detailed exploration of its interactions with other chemicals.
